segments.text: Because up to that time, we were not teaching neuro.
The student in anatomy knew the brain and the gross parts of the brain, and that was about all.
And he had to know more than that as a basis for his clinical material and for physiology, because they were getting into neurophysiology then.
the central nervous system was becoming more and more important as time went on, because we were getting more drugs that acted on central nervous system and what have you.
So you have to be aware of what's happening, and you have to know the part that you're working on.
Just as I told, I was in a meeting of the American College of Veterinary Pathologists in Chicago at the Kellogg Center, oh, I guess about 15 years ago.
And I criticize the pathologists for not knowing their neuroanatomy.
You pick up an article and here's a disease on the central nervous system.
It affects the cerebellum or it affects the brain stem.
And they tell you nothing about where it is, what motor nucleus or sensory nucleus or what tract or anything else that's involved.
It's just in this great big piece of brain.
It's not pinned down anywhere.
So how can you draw any deductions on that?
You cannot.
Except that it's an involvement of the central nervous system.
Or as a veterinarian used to say, he's got some kind of central nervous system disease.
Some kind of.
Some kind of a nervous system disease.
And that's about all he knew about it.
So I did get that.
I did get a good course in neuroanatomy.
And when I came back here in the early 50s, then we began making up class sets of every animal species or domestic animal.
The cow and the horse, the sheep and the cat and the dog and chickens and what have you, turkeys and anything else, and monkeys.
Baylor Medical School was very nice to me.
I don't know how many human brains they let me have.
And I worked up class sets in human brains.
And we went from the human to the cow and the horse and so on.
We took what we learned from the human, because we had a human textbook, the same that they were using in Galveston Medical School.
And we went from there down into domestic animals for comparison.
It was, of course, in comparison.
That sounds tremendous.
It was, even if I do say so.
No, that sounds like just a great idea.
The students didn't like it.
Why not?
Simply because the practicing veterinarians who didn't know neuroanatomy.
What are you studying that stuff for?
What are you going to do about it if you find they've got some kind of a nervous condition?
What are you going to do about it?
So the students, some of them got the idea that this is a waste of time studying all this stuff.
So I had to fight that idea too.
But now it's a- I think it would help them with understanding.
Comparative medicine, I think, would be very important.
Isn't there a new, in veterinary medicine, let's turn to veterinary medicine, just the discipline of veterinary medicine.
It appears to me that there's been more, after talking to a number of your colleagues, that there's been a more and more specialization.
Absolutely.
From the time that you graduated until today.
And, of course, with more and more PhDs too than ever before.
And isn't comparative medicine one of those fields?
Absolutely.
Yes, sir.
So I said to the students, you are going to have medical doctors as clients.
Yeah.
And they are going to ask you questions if this animal happens to have a central nervous system involvement.
They're going to want to know, where is the lesion?
And what are you going to say?
You don't know?
Some place in the brain.
Some place in the brain, or somewhere.
I think gradually they began to adapt to the idea of neuroanatomy.
I had that feeling.
Now, one of our graduates in veterinary medicine is at Johns Hopkins now.
Oh, really?
And she's in neuropathology.
And she wishes to high heaven that she had listened to me more in the course in neuroanatomy.
So I said, you can't tell.
You can't tell what you're going to be doing.
Just like Ty Hardy.
When Ty Hardy was going through here, our only graduate in 1930, he didn't care anything about small animals.
All he wanted was large animals.
He didn't want to fool with dogs and cats.
Who's going to fool with those things?
Well, when he got out, what did he do?
Sheep and stuff and small animals?
Huh?
So you never know.
What do you think about this 10 trend toward specialization?
What's your opinion of that?
Well, I really don't know.
I really don't know.
I never went into that myself.
What's going to become of it?
It all depends on the population growth and the animal
growth, the population of animals and so on, the number of veterinarians that we have, and the specializations that they're doing.
I really don't know.
To me, that's to come up.
I don't know how they're going to do anything.
I know up to this time why it's been a rather broad specialization, either small animals or large animals.
or a milk and meat inspection work or something like that.
Some of them, all animals, whether large or small.
And some of them only cats, and some of them only dogs.
They seem to be doing all right.
Financially, I guess they're doing all right.
Everyone I've seen says he's doing fine.
Of course, that used to be the way you'd go to a veterinary meeting, a conference, and you'd see all these old boys that graduated back there when you do.
You did.
How you getting along?
Oh, man, I'm really doing well.
I just don't have any overhead at all.
All I got to help him is a little black boy, and that's all the overhead, you know.
You know darn well he's not doing that well.
I think most of them have done well, they've done well in real estate, and they put their money wisely in other things.
But I really don't know about specializations.
Okay, one last question for tonight, and can we get together again?
Sure, anytime you want to.
Okay, and that concerns...
the granting of graduate degrees here.

Our first Doctor of Veterinary Medicine was granted in 1920, and then it was 15, 20 years later before the first Masters, and it wasn't until 1955 that we granted our first PhD in Veterinary Medicine.
Why did it take so long?
It would be veterinary medicine.
I wouldn't say veterinarian medicine.
Yeah, exactly.
Veterinary medicine.
Why did it take so long?
Who did we have to give a degree?
Who did we have to give an advanced degree?
We didn't have anybody who had a PhD.
If you're going to give a PhD, shouldn't a PhD give it?
Most of them just had a degree in veterinary medicine, and that's all they ever hoped to get.
This was like advanced degrees in medical college.
I asked some of the fellas down in Galveston, what about advanced degrees for you boys who have EMDs?
Who's going to teach us?
That's what the question is.
Who's going to teach us?
the ultimate.
Who's going to teach us?
So to me, it's very much the same way now in veterinary medicine.
If you have a degree in veterinary medicine, heaven help us just for the catechism you go through, what do you want with more?
But we have, at one time,

and this hasn't been too far back the degree in veterinary medicine was a baccalaureate degree and we came last at graduation after all the other graduates walked across the stage v for veterinary came last and i said mr heaton why is that so you're just a baccalaureate degree you just have four years
I said, well, it's Doctor of Veterinary Medicine.
Well, it's just a baccalaureate degree.
And we went under that cloud for many, many years.
So degree in veterinary medicine, why, it was just like an AB or BS.
Right.
And that may have been in the back of my mind when I went on and got my PhD, just for prestige on the campus.
What did I learn?
I learned some neuroanatomy.
Do you think that was in the back of your mind?
Yeah, that was in the back of my mind.
As one of our friends here in chemistry, a PhD in chemistry from Illinois,
If you got a PhD in education, you didn't have a degree.
You had to have an earned degree in one of those basic sciences, like chemistry.
Then you had, this is his words, the degree.
Yeah.
You have a degree in veterinary medicine and I don't know, they sort of stuck in their crawl when they called you doctor.
Because that's just a baccalaureate degree.
Of course then we began to say two years of pre-vet and so on and so on and now so many of them have
Four years, degrees and so on.
Before they even get to it.
Before they even get into veterinary medicine.
Same way in human medicine.
Time was in human medicine, four years.
That was it.
And well, from high school to medical college.
And the old family doctor we had in Crockett, he said when he finished his sophomore year in Tulane, he went out in the,
sawmill town in East Texas and practiced in the summers.
And he said he had to remove arms and legs that got mangled up in the sawmills and so on.
He knew more about the anatomy than anybody else.
And so he was the guy.
And as a sophomore from medical school, he was out there doing surgery.
But medicine has come so far, so has veterinary medicine.
And of course, the research that's gone on in the pharmacology and physiology and so on.
The drugs, the new drugs that are coming out every day.
Now it's interferon, maybe for cancer and so on.
The electron microscope, electronics, it's miraculous.
It really is, isn't it?
Well, we're going to talk about, next time we're going to talk about the 1940s to the present.
Well, good.
OK. That's all right.
So thank you very much for this interview.
This ends the interview.
This is Terry Anderson.
